Augusta University Research Institute (AURI) has no employees. Officers of AURI are employed by Augusta University, or are outside unpaid community members, and are compensated for the role performed for Augusta University if they are employees. Officers of AURI are also Officers of Augusta University which is subcontractor on all sponsored program funding received by AURI.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 7 Bonuses are awarded based on individual performance and determined by the achievements of objectives or Key Performance Indicators. These payments are not contingent on revenues of the organization.

The University requires the president to live in on-campus housing and provides a custodian to clean the facility. The University maintains a country club membership in the president's name for entertainment of donors. It is acceptable that the president's spouse or significant other may accompany him on University business trips/events. During these trips/events, the expense of the spouse or significant other will be paid by the University.

The Executive Committee of the Board has authorized the President to travel first class air on trips over four hours. The President & CEO's spouse accompanies him on trips to Board meetings and other events where she entertains trustee spouses, holding breakfasts, lunches, and leading tours and other outings. The President & CEO must obtain approval from the Board chairman each time his spouse accompanies him.

The College's Compensation Committee, composed of Board members, determines the base compensation and annual incentive award of the President & CEO. They also review and approve the President & CEO's recommendations for other members of the College's senior leadership team. The award amounts are tied to individual performance and based on a qualitative evaluation of the accomplishment of goals that are determined at the beginning of the year.

Laurence Barton, former President and CEO, received $592,875 including salary of $143,077 that coverd the period January through November 2016 and a contract buyout of $479,798 that covered the period December 2016 through December 2018. Neal R. Fegely, former Chief Financial & Risk Officer received $347,301 including $ 215,217 in severance in the form of salary continuation covering February 2016 through December 2016, January 2016 salary and a payout of accumulated unused paid time off (PTO) of $59,782, and a long-term incentive payment of $72,302.

The College had long-term incentive plans (LTIP) for three different periods in place in 2016. The final payment for the plan covering 2011 - 2013 was made in 2016 to the former Chief Operating Officer and Chief Marketing Officer. The first of two payments (the second will be made in 2017) for an LTIP covering 2014 and 2015 was made to four participants (the current Chief Operating Officer, the Chief Marketing Officer, the Chief Technology Officer, and the VP of Organizational Effectiveness). The College's Senior Leadership Team participates in the third LTIP that covers the period 2016 - 2018 and is based on revenue and students served. To receive payments under this plan, participants must be employed through December 2018. Payments will be made equally from 2019 to 2021.

The College had two long-term incentive plans (LTIP) with criteria that included net income in place in 2016. The final payment for the plan covering 2011 - 2013 was made in 2016 to the former Chief Operating Officer and Chief Marketing Officer. The first of two payments (the second will be made in 2017) for an LTIP covering 2014 and 2015 was made to four participants (the current Chief Operating Officer, the Chief Marketing Officer, the chief Technology Officer, and the VP of Organizational Effectiveness).

The CAMCHSI Board of Directors Compensation Committee selects and supervises an independent consultant who advises the Committee on compensation arrangements and transactions between CAMC Health System, Inc. subsidiaries (including CHERI) and executives (including CHERI's President). The Committee uses the data to determine the total compensation of CHERI's President and the other executives. The data is reviewed every two years or when a new person comes into an executive role.

Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan ("SERP"). Participants are key officers of CAMCHSI and subsidiaries. Ronald E. Moore, CHERI Director participated in a 457F plan and received a payout of $1,805,731 from the plan. Terms and Conditions of SERP plan: Defined Benefit. Vest at age 60, or later, if one time postponement is made prior to age 59. Deferred vesting date cannot be earlier than age 65 or later than age 68. Benefit at age 60 with 30 years of service is computed as the difference between 55% of Final Average Total compensation and sum of retirement benefits paid from: CAMC Health System, Inc. Qualified Retirement Plan, Non-Qualified Retirement Restoration Plan and 50% of projected age 62 Primary Social Security Benefit. Eligible to receive SERP benefits upon earliest of: normal retirement or date elected, if extended; death; disability; involuntary termination without cause. Early retirement at age 55 with at least 5 years of service reduced 1.83% for each year of service less 30 and 0.5% reduction for each month prior to Normal Retirement Date (age 60). Taxes due upon distribution. Subject to the Substantial Risk of Forfeiture. CEO Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan ("SERP"): Participant-CEO Terms and Conditions of CEO SERP Plan: Defined Contribution. Vest at age 65. Benefit at age 65 projected as the difference between 60% of Final 5 Year Average Total compensation and sum of retirement benefits paid from: CAMC Health System, Inc. Qualified Retirement Plan and 50% of projected age 65 Primary Social Security Benefit. Actual benefits will depend upon simulated investment results based on investment options selected by participant. Eligible to receive SERP benefits upon earliest of: deferred vesting date; death; disability; involuntary termination without cause. Taxes due upon vesting. Subject to the Substantial Risk of Forfeiture. Under the Execu-Flex Benefit Plan (409A), executives receive 11% of their salary in flex allowance. The flex allowance is used to elect executive benefits. Any remaining flex allowance is credited to a tax-deferred Capital Accumulation Account. The minimum vesting period is two years, maximum is age 68. A two year non-compete agreement (Substantial Risk of Forfeiture Agreement) applies if termination of employment occurs prior to the vesting date. Certain participants had amounts vested and included as reportable compensation this year, as detailed below: Sharon A. Hall - $29,706 Robert D. Whitler - $18,440 Glenn Crotty Jr., M.D. - $72,240 Ronald E. Moore - $20,291 David L. Ramsey - $82,157 Kristi Snyder - $19,120

Benefits earned under the SERP are nonvested forms of deferred compensation that fund the employee's eventual retirement benefit. These benefits are provided in exchange for all the employee's years of service to the organization. The amounts are at risk and will not be paid unless and until the employee has provided substantial future services to the organization. Benefits under the SERP vest if the employee remains employed at the organization through January 1, 2018 and are forfeited if the employee is terminated for cause by the organization or if the employee leaves the organization voluntarily prior to January 1, 2018.

THE MOUNT SINAI HOSPITAL, A RELATED ORGANIZATION, ANSWERED YES TO QUESTIONS 6A AND 6B IN SCHEDULE J AS THE INSTITUTION UTILIZES AN INCENTIVE BASED BONUS PROGRAM FOR CERTAIN EMPLOYEES, INCLUDING SEVERAL OF THOSE EMPLOYEES LISTED IN SCHEDULE J. NET EARNINGS IS ONE OF SEVERAL METRICS UTILIZED BY THE INSTITUTION IN THE ANNUAL BONUS CALCULATION. INDIVIDUALS THAT HAVE RESPONSIBILITIES IN RELATED ORGANIZATIONS TO THE HOSPITAL MAY HAVE INCENTIVES BASED ON THE PERFORMANCE OF THESE ORGANIZATIONS AS WELL AS THAT OF THE HOSPITAL.

THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT RESIDES IN A UNIVERSITY OWNED HOUSE. THE HOUSE IS USED FOR UNIVERSITY FUNCTIONS INCLUDING RECEPTIONS, DINNERS AND OTHER BUSINESS EVENTS. THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSING IS THEREFORE INCLUDED IN NONTAXABLE COMPENSATION.

PART I, LINE 1A HOUSING ALLOWANCE: THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO LIVE ON-CAMPUS IN THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT AND, THEREFORE, THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS NOT TAXABLE. PERSONAL SERVICES: A COLLEGE EMPLOYEE PREPARES MEALS AT THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGE. A COLLEGE EMPLOYEE FROM ITS FACILITIES MAINTENANCE DEPARTMENT IS ASSIGNED TO THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. THE HOME IS MAINTAINED SIMILARLY TO OTHER CAMPUS FACILITIES. IN ADDITION TO CLEANING AND MAINTAINING THE PUBLIC AREAS OF THE RESIDENCE, THE INDIVIDUAL PERFORMS A SMALL AMOUNT OF LIGHT HOUSEKEEPING (INCLUDING DUSTING AND VACUUMING)IN THE PRESIDENT'S PERSONAL QUARTERS. THIS HOUSEKEEPING IS CONSIDERED TO BE OF NO ADDITIONAL COST TO THE INSTITUTION. A COLLEGE CAR AND DRIVER ARE PROVIDED WHEN TRAVELING ON COLLEGE BUSINESS. THESE BENEFITS ARE NONTAXABLE. THE PRESIDENT REIMBURSES THE COLLEGE FOR ANY NON-BUSINESS USE OF THE CAR AND DRIVER DURING THE YEAR.

PART I, LINE 7 THE COLLEGE DEDICATES A SMALL AMOUNT OF A BONUS POOL TO EACH MEMBER OF THE PRESIDENT'S CABINET TO AWARD WITHIN THEIR DIVISIONS. BONUSES ARE NOT CONTRACTUALLY BASED ON SALES, PRODUCTION, ETC... INSTEAD, THEY ARE TYPICALLY GIVEN FOR EXTRA EFFORT, COMPLETION OF A PROJECT, ETC... AND, THEY ARE TYPICALLY AWARDED AFTER-THE-FACT.

EXPLANATION OF HOUSING ALLOWANCE: A HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS ANY PAYMENT FOR, OR PROVISION OF, HOUSING BY THE ORGANIZATION FOR PERSONAL USE BY AN EMPLOYEE. TO QUALIFY FOR SPECIAL TAX TREATMENT, THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE GENERALLY MUST EITHER RELATE TO A QUALIFIED MINISTER OR IN RELATION TO LODGING FURNISHED BY AN EMPLOYER TO AN EMPLOYEE, A SPOUSE, OR DEPENDENTS FOR THE EMPLOYER'S CONVENIENCE, FURNISHED ON THE EMPLOYER'S BUSINESS PREMISES FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER. DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR 2016, THE REV. DR. KATHARINE HENDERSON WAS PAID A HOUSING ALLOWANCE OF $40,000. THE REV. JOHN H. VAUGHN WAS PAID A HOUSING ALLOWANCE OF $40,524. PAUL RAUSHENBUSH WAS PAID A HOUSING ALLOWANCE OF $35,000. THIS IS NONTAXABLE AND REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, D.

The Board of Trustees has enacted procedures to establish a presumption that the total compensation offered to officers and key employees is reasonable, consistent with Internal Revenue Code Section 4958 and applicable regulations. These procedures include: a decision-making committee comprised solely of trustees who are independent and free of conflict of interest (the Executive Committee); reliance on market comparability data; use of independent compensation consultants, as needed; and documentation of the committee's work.

First-class or charter travel- First-class is not authorized for employees traveling on College business, without advanced approval by the President or appropriate Vice President. In recognition that the President typically works during flights and attends directly to College business upon arrival, the Board of Trustees has approved the limited use of first-class travel for the President when traveling on College business. Charter travel was used on a limited basis for travel, including by President, CFO and other employees, funded by way of a restricted gift. Travel for companions- Travel for companions is permitted only when the companion's travel is directly in furtherance of the College's business purposes. Housing allowance or residence- Housing is provided to the President as a required condition of employment. All benefits were provided in accordance with written College policies. None of the benefits were treated as taxable compensation in accordance with applicable law.

The Chair of the Board provides the Executive Committee with his/her analysis of the President's performance and asks for further feedback and performance related comments during an executive session without the President present. The President is asked to provide the Chair of the Board with a detailed self evaluation, with highlights and areas of concern shared with the full Board. Based on performance evaluation, current compensation and comparison to similar positions of liked sized colleges located in the Midwest, annual compensation decisions are made and the Board approves. The process for determination of compensation for key personnel includes a survey of salaries of similar colleges in the Midwest and through use of CUPA-HR salary survey information (College and University Professional Association for Human Resources). This is a national organization with regional chapters that collect wage and salary information through surveys. This information is provided to the President and appropriate Vice Presidents by the wage and benefit coordinator. All recommendations of the Vice Presidents are approved by the President of the College.

Travel for companions: Occasionally spouses of officers accompany them on business trips for the College. In order to be treated as a working condition fringe benefit, the College requires substantiation of the trip as a bonafide business expense for both the officer and the spouse. If there is no business purpose for the spouse, the spousal travel is treated as taxable income to the officer or the officer reimburses the College. Housing allowance or residence for personal use: One listed person received this benefit. The President is required to live in on-campus housing for hosting purposes and 24/7 availability to the campus community. Because of this requirement, it is excluded from wages under Section 119 of the IRS code. The housing value included in non-taxable compensation was $36,915.

Certain employees were given bonuses for exceeding the goals and expectations assigned to them for the year. Recommendations for bonuses are made by the President to the executive committee of the board. The executive committee of the board reviews and approves the bonuses.
A discretionary spending account is available to key employees for business purposes. As well each employee receives a discretionary health spending amount.

The University has a travel policy that outlines allowable expenses. Please refer to the Financial Services Policy section on our website: http://www.queensu.ca/financialservices/polices. This policy is in accordance with applicable federal and provincial legislation including but not limited to legislation issued by the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) and the Broader Public Sector (BPS) Accountability ACt, 2010 and all related directives.

The Board of Trustees has multiple committees of which one is the Human Resources committee. This committee annually reviews and evaluates comments of the board and key stakeholders regarding the performance of the Principal and also reviews the overall compensation of the Principal. The committee also monitors executive and senior institutional management salaries and provides direction to management for labour negotiations and collective bargaining for all University Employees. The university is supported by the provincial government and is subject to Ontario Legislation related to compensation and this is taken into account and applied as necessary. More details can be found at http://www.queensu.ca/secretariat/board-trustees/committee/human-resources -committee.

The University provides a residence for the President on campus. The residence is a condition of employment as stated in the President's appointment letter. The house is provided to enable the President to be on campus 24/7 in order to respond to emergent situations that may arise and for other business purposes.

The University maintains a 457(b) deferred compensation plan for executive level employees. This plan was developed consistent with the 2001 Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act (EGTRRA). The University does not contribute to the plan (employee contributions only). 2016 employee contributions (not included in column B): Paul Greengard $18,000 Virginia Huffman $18,000 Maren Imhoff $18,000 James Lapple $18,000 Richard Lifton $24,000 Roberta Maloney $18,000 Harriet Rabb $18,000 Robert Roeder $18,000 Sidney Strickland $18,000 Michael Young $18,000

The University maintains a bonus plan for the Chief Investment Officer and the Deputy Chief Investment Officer which is partially based upon the fiscal year return of the University's endowment in addition to other quantitative and qualitative measures. The plan was approved by the University's Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees. The plan was developed using comparative data from similar institutions. For retention purposes, a portion of the annual bonus is deferred and paid in subsequent years.

The University maintains a policy to provide recruitment and retention supplements to faculty as necessary. The purpose of this supplement is to provide an incentive for a candidate to join the University and for incumbent faculty to make Rockefeller their professional home, recognizing the high cost of living in the New York metropolitan area over the course of a whole career. The decision whether to grant a supplement and its size will turn on the exceptional quality of the faculty member's research and the strategic needs of the University, and will be made by the President in the exercise of his discretion.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 3 The Presidents compensation is determined and approved by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees. This committee utilizes information from the 990 returns of other benchmark institutions, compensation surveys of other private colleges and universities, and other benchmarks obtained by the members of the committee as information in the compensation determination process. These discussions are documented in the minutes and files of the compensation committee.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: COMPENSATION CONTINGENT UPON THE REVENUES OF THE ORGANIZATION
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 5A The Compensation Committee implemented a Compensation Philosophy for the officers of the organization through the application of the following considerations: * Base salary will be set so that the targeted positioning of an Officer is the 50th percentile of the target market for each position. Base salary for an individual Officer relative to the target market pay will be set by the President based on the individual's unique background, experiences, personal skills and abilities (including creativity, growth-orientation and discipline) as well as based on the business challenges facing the Organization which require the use of such attributes or skills. * Annual incentive compensation, if any, will be delivered according to a guideline that approximates the market 75th percentile total cash compensation for commensurate performance. The Committee has the discretion to deliver annual incentives above or below the 75th percentile based on individual circumstances and performance conditions. The aim of annual incentives is to drive and reward consistent improvement in performance. Goals to achieve an incentive payout include, but are not limited to, targets at different levels for total revenues of the organization.

AN AUTOMOBILE AND HOUSING RESIDENCE IS FURNISHED FOR THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1A FIRST CLASS TRAVEL - ALTHOUGH IT IS THE UNIVERSITY'S GENERAL PRACTICE TO ONLY PAY FOR COACH AIRFARE, AIR TRAVEL OTHER THAN COACH (EITHER FIRST OR BUSINESS CLASS) FOR OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES IS LIMITED TO EITHER DESTINATIONS OUTSIDE THE CONTINENTAL U.S. OR WHEN FIRST OR BUSINESS CLASS AIRFARE IS THE ONLY AVAILABLE AIRFARE BASED ON NECESSARY TRAVEL DATES. UNIVERSITY POLICY REQUIRES ADDITIONAL DOCUMENTATION IN THE CASE OF FIRST OR BUSINESS CLASS AIRFARE TO DOCUMENT THE REASON OF THE ADDITIONAL EXPENSE. CHARTER TRAVEL - THE UNIVERSITY CHARTERS AIRCRAFTS FOR THE PURPOSE OF TRANSPORTING UNIVERSITY ATHLETIC TEAMS TO VARIOUS INTERCOLLEGIATE ATHLETIC EVENT LOCATIONS. IN INSTANCES WHERE A UNIVERSITY EMPLOYEE AND\OR THEIR FAMILY MEMBER TRAVELS ON A UNIVERSITY CHARTERED FLIGHT, WITHOUT A UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE, THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWS THE RULES UNDER IRS REGULATION SECTION 1.61-21(G) TO DETERMINE THE TAXABLE VALUE, WHICH MAY BE ZERO, OF THE CHARTERED TRAVEL PROVIDED TO THE EMPLOYEE AND/OR THEIR FAMILY MEMBER. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE - PERSONAL USE OF HOUSING IS GENERALLY BASED ON THE PROVISIONS OF AN EMPLOYEES SERVICES AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY. THE VALUE OF THE HOUSING PROVIDED IS NOT TAXABLE TO THE INDIVIDUAL TO THE EXTENT IT IS A CONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT. THE VALUE OF HOUSING, WHICH IS PROVIDED, BUT NOT AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, IS TAXABLE TO THE INDIVIDUAL AND REPORTED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II AS OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION IN COLUMN (COL B(III)). TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS THE UNIVERSITY OCCASIONALLY PAYS FOR THE TRAVEL OF A STAFF MEMBERS SPOUSE. THESE INSTANCES ARE GENERALLY LIMITED TO SITUATIONS WHERE EITHER THE SPOUSES TRAVEL IS CONSIDERED TO HAVE A UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE OR AS PART OF A STAFF MEMBERS SERVICES AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY. THE UNIVERSITY FURTHER LIMITS SPOUSAL BUSINESS TRAVEL FOR INSTANCES WHERE IT BELIEVES THEIR PRESENCE IS IN THE BEST INTERESTS OF THE UNIVERSITY AND DOES NOT REPORT THESE AMOUNTS AS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION. THE UNIVERSITY DOES REPORT, AS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION, SPOUSAL TRAVEL PROVIDED AS PART OF A STAFF MEMBERS SERVICES AGREEMENT AND WHERE THERE IS NO UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE TRAVEL. ADDITIONALLY, ON RARE OCCASION A STAFF MEMBERS SPOUSE MAY ACCOMPANY A DEPAUL ATHLETIC TEAM ON A CHARTERED AIRCRAFT, IF EXCESS SEATING IS AVAILABLE. PLEASE SEE THE ABOVE CHARTER TRAVEL DISCLOSURE FOR ADDITIONAL DETAILS REGARDING SUCH INSTANCES. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS - SUCH PAYMENTS ARE GENERALLY PROVIDED BASED ON THE PROVISIONS OF AN EMPLOYEES SERVICES AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE INCLUDED IN COLUMN B(III) OF PART II. PERSONAL SERVICES - SUCH PAYMENTS ARE GENERALLY PROVIDED BASED ON THE PROVISIONS OF AN EMPLOYEES SERVICES AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY. PAYMENTS FOR SUCH ITEMS ARE TAXABLE TO THE INDIVIDUAL AND REPORTED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II AS OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION IN COLUMN (COL B(III)).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: WRITTEN POLICY REGARDING PAYMENT OR REIMBURSEMENT
ExplntnTxt: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1B THE ITEMS INDICATED FOR LINE 1A, OTHER THAN FIRST CLASS TRAVEL, CHARTER TRAVEL, AND TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS, ARE GENERALLY PROVIDED PURSUANT TO AN EMPLOYEES SERVICE AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY. WHERE APPROPRIATE, THE AMOUNTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE ITEMS ARE INCLUDED IN THE TOTAL COMPENSATION AS DETERMINED UNDER THE REBUTTABLE PRESUMPTION PROCEDURES ADOPTED BY THE UNIVERSITY FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION FOR DISQUALIFIED PERSONS. PLEASE REFER TO THE SCHEDULE O EXPLANATION FOR FORM 990, PART VI-B, LINE 15 FOR A DESCRIPTION OF THE UNIVERSITYS PROCESS FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION FOR DISQUALIFIED PERSONS.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 7: FOR THOSE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1A, WHO ARE ELIGIBLE, BONUSES ARE PAID PURSUANT TO THEIR SERVICE AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY. SUCH AGREEMENTS GENERALLY CONTAIN EITHER A DOLLAR OR PERCENTAGE OF BASE SALARY LIMIT UP TO WHICH THE INDIVIDUAL IS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE AS A BONUS FOR A FISCAL YEAR. ACTUAL BONUS AMOUNTS RECEIVED ARE BASED ON ATTAINING CERTAIN PERFORMANCE GOALS SET BY THE UNIVERSITY. IN ADDITION, ALL FULL-TIME STAFF, EXCLUDING EXECUTIVE LEVEL EMPLOYEES, ARE ELIGIBLE FOR THE UNIVERSITYS STAFF RECOGNITION AND REWARD PROGRAM. THIS PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO IDENTIFY AND REWARD SUCH DISTINCTIVE AND EXCEPTIONAL ACHIEVEMENTS BY STAFF EMPLOYEES WHO MAINTAIN THEIR DAY-TO-DAY DUTIES AT AN EXCEPTIONAL LEVEL. THE PROGRAM RECOGNIZES ACHIEVEMENTS THAT GO ABOVE AND BEYOND THE EMPLOYEE'S CORE DUTIES WHEN THEY EXHIBIT ACTIONS THAT SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE UNIVERSITYS OR DEPARTMENTAL INITIATIVES, EXCEPTIONAL CUSTOMER SERVICE, OR IDEAS THAT IMPROVE OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY. SUCH AWARDS ARE TREATED AS BONUS COMPENSATION AMOUNTS BY THE UNIVERSITY. DURING THE SCHEDULE J COMPENSATION REPORTING PERIOD, MR. JOSE PERALES RECEIVED AN AWARD UNDER THE PROGRAM AND AFTER HIS TERM AS INTERIM VICE PRESIDENT FOR INSTITUTIONAL DIVERSITY ENDED.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 8 DEPAUL HAS CERTAIN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS WHICH MAY QUALIFY FOR THE INITIAL CONTRACT EXCEPTION UNDER IRC REGULATION 53.4958-4(A)(3). MR. SANTINO CARINGELLA ASSUMED THE POSITION OF TREASURER AND ENTERED INTO A SERVICES AGREEMENT WITH THE UNIVERSITY ON APRIL 18, 2016. MR. CARINGELLA'S COMPENSATION, PURSUANT TO HIS SERVICES AGREEMENT, WAS DETERMINED UNDER THE UNIVERSITY'S PROCESS FOR ESTABLISHING A REBUTTABLE PRESUMPTION OF REASONABLENESS AS DESCRIBED IN IRC REGULATION 53.4958-6(C). SEE SCHEDULE O FOR A DETAILED EXPLANATION OF THIS PROCESS. MR. CARINGELLA WAS NOT AN EMPLOYEE OF THE UNIVERSITY PRIOR TO HIS APPOINTMENT AS REFERENCED ABOVE.

THE SALARY AMOUNTS SHOWN FOR REVEREND HOLTSCHNEIDER ARE PAID DIRECTLY TO THE EASTERN PROVINCE OF THE CONGREGATION OF THE MISSION RELIGIOUS ORDER. THE SALARY AMOUNTS SHOWN FOR REVERENDS RICHARDSON AND UDOVIC ARE PAID DIRECTLY TO THE WESTERN PROVINCE OF THE CONGREGATION OF THE MISSION RELIGIOUS ORDER.

THROUGH THE RELATED ORGANIZATION THAT EMPLOYS THEM, THE INDIVIDUALS REPORTED IN PART VII OF FORM 990 AND IN SCHEDULE J (FORM 990) GENERALLY PARTICIPATE IN THE FLORIDA RETIREMENT SYSTEM (FRS), A MULTI-EMPLOYER RETIREMENT SYSTEM CREATED UNDER CHAPTER 121 OF THE FLORIDA STATUTES AND ADMINISTERED BY THE FLORIDA DIVISION OF RETIREMENT. AS STATED ON THE WEBSITE OF FRS, IT IS FUNDED BY CONTRIBUTIONS PAID BY EMPLOYERS, BASED ON A PERCENTAGE OF THE EMPLOYEES' SALARIES. THE RATE OF CONTRIBUTIONS REQUIRED IS DETERMINED BY AN ACTUARIAL CONSULTING FIRM TO ASSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE CONSTITUTION OF THE STATE OF FLORIDA. THE INSTRUCTIONS FOR FORM 990 INDICATE THAT PART VII AND SCHEDULE J SHOULD INCLUDE A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE INCREASE IN THE ACTUARIAL VALUE OF ANY QUALIFIED OR NONQUALIFIED RETIRMENT ACCRUALS UNDER A DEFINED BENEFIT PLAN. FRS HAS STATED THAT SUCH INFORMATION CURRENTLY IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR PARTICIPANTS IN ITS PLAN. THEREFORE, THE AMOUNTS REPORTED IN PART VII AND SCHEDULE J, AS APPROPRIATE, INCLUDE THE CONTRIBUTION PAID BY THE RELATED ORGANIZATION AS ITS CONTRIBUTION ON BEHALF OF THE NAMED INDIVIDUAL. THIS AMOUNT IS CONSIDERED THE BEST REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF INFORMATION REQUIRED IN THE FORM 990 AND RELATED SCHEDULES.

AMOUNTS PAID FOR TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS ARE INCLUDED AS TAXABLE WAGES FOR OFFICERS. THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE AND PERSONAL SERVICES IS FOR THE HOUSE THAT MOUNT MERCY UNIVERSITY OWNS AND THE PRESIDENT RESIDES IN WHERE SHE CONDUCTS SIGNIFICANT BUSINESS ACTIVITIES AND HOLDS COLLEGE RELATED ENTERTAINMENT FUNCTIONS. SOCIAL CLUB DUES PAID BY THE ORGANIZATION ARE ALLOCATED BETWEEN BUSINESS AND PERSONAL BASED ON USAGE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: Former President and Chancellor (current officer at time expenses were incurred) used charter flights to conduct University business, such as attending meetings, speaking engagements and donor cultivation events. Interim President also used charter flights in conducting business such as interviewing a job candidate and attending meetings. Vice President for University Development and Executive Vice President & Provost used charter flights to attend donor cultivation events and business meetings. Vice President for Constituent Engagement used a charter flight to attend a donor cultivation event. Vice President for Student Life used a charter flight to attend a Title IX meeting. Vice President for Operations & Facilities and Vice President for Academic Operations & Strategic Finance used a charter flight to attend a business meeting. Both the former (current officer at time expenses were incurred) and current Vice President & Director of Intercollegiate Athletics used charter flights to attend business meetings. Highly compensated employees traveled on charter flights with their respective athletic teams to attend athletic events. Some Baylor Regents and/or officers occasionally traveled on charter flights provided for Athletic Department team travel to engage in donor development efforts and event oversight on behalf of the University. Charter flights were used by highly compensated employees for student athletic recruiting purposes, attending events such as Big 12 media days, donor related activities, Big 12 coaches meetings, NCAA meetings, speaking engagements, and NFL draft selecting Baylor athletes. Charter flights were reviewed by the University and any part of a flight that was not business related was reported as taxable compensation. Former President and Chancellor (current officer at time expenses were incurred) traveled first-class on approximately five flights during 2016. Interim President traveled first-class on one flight during 2016. Travel by the Former President and Chancellor and Interim President was reviewed by the Regent's Audit and Compliance Committee including all first-class travel. Vice President for University Development and Executive Vice President & Provost each traveled first-class for one flight in 2016. All travel for these two officers was presented to the Regent's Audit and Compliance Committee for review. University provided Interim Head Football Coach first class trip to Baylor when he was being introduced as new head football coach. University provided a first class flight for Interim Head Football Coach for trip between Waco and his home during his one year interim coaching position. This flight was reported as taxable income.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: Occasionally, guests or family members of listed persons were provided travel. The University policy and practice is to review travel activities that occur throughout the year and report the value of such travel as taxable compensation to listed persons if no bona fide business purpose existed for the companion travel.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Tax indemnification and gross-up payments
ExplntnTxt: Men's and Women's head basketball coaches had personal travel stipends grossed-up to provide contractual amount owed by the University. Vice President for University Development received gross-up payments per employment arrangement covering the additional taxes owed on supplemental payments for his children's tuition costs. University grossed-up monthly payments made to Vice President and Director of Intercollegiate Athletics, which were provided to cover monthly amounts for buyout amount owed to previous employer. Severance payment and a few miscellaneous taxable benefits provided to Former President and Chancellor were grossed-up. Transition expenses incurred for start of new Vice President for Marketing & Communications and Chief Marketing Officer at University were grossed up. All above described payments were reported as taxable income, including the tax on the gross-up payments. Additionally, the University may occasionally gross-up other payments, but all such payments are included in the taxable income of the applicable employee.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Housing allowance or residence for personal use
ExplntnTxt: Interim President and Former Interim Executive Vice President & Provost received a minister's housing allowance which was associated with the provision of services related to duties and thus appropriately not reported as taxable compensation. Baylor provided Vice President for University Development and Vice President and Director of Intercollegiate Athletics with temporary housing during their transition to beginning work at the University. This temporary housing was reported as taxable income. Baylor provided former (current officer at time expenses were incurred) and current Executive Vice President & Provost with housing per their employment agreements. This housing was reported as taxable income. Interim Head football coach was provided temporary housing during his one year tenure at Baylor. This housing was reported as taxable income. Baylor provided Former President and Chancellor with a house as a condition of employment and for the convenience of the University. The provision of the house was not included as taxable compensation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Health or social club dues or initiation fees
ExplntnTxt: Certain officers and highly compensated employees were provided country club memberships in one or two local clubs. All club memberships were reported as taxable compensation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Personal services
ExplntnTxt: Baylor provided housekeeping services for the University house during the portion of calendar 2016 in which the former President and Chancellor was serving as the current President and Chancellor. The portion of the housekeeping expenses used for personal purposes was included as taxable income.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1b Written policy regarding payment or reimbursement of expenses
ExplntnTxt: The University has a written policy for the following benefits: first-class travel and charter travel, and travel for companions. The Baylor aircraft policy is only applicable to Baylor-provided charter travel. Other charter travel used by the Athletic Department for team travel is based upon the need of the sport. Social club memberships are reported as taxable income. Tax indemnification and gross-up payments are included in contractual arrangements and/or require Board of Regents approval. The Former President and Chancellor's housing was provided as a condition of employment per the terms of his contract, and the house was provided for the convenience of the University. Housekeeping services are handled as noted above.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4a Severance or change-of-control payment
ExplntnTxt: Former Senior Vice President for University Development & Strategic Initiatives separated from employment in 2014 and continued to receive severance pay in 2016 per the agreement. The pay in 2016 totaled $407,494 and qualifies as bona fide severance pay per Code section 457(E)(11). The University withheld appropriate taxes from each monthly payment. Per the agreement, the severance pay is to be reduced by any amount of compensation the former Senior Vice President for University Development & Strategic Initiatives receives from the University or any other employer. Former President and Chancellor received gross severance pay of $4,520,119 during calendar year 2016. Former Executive Vice President and Provost received gross severance pay of $1,000,000 during calendar year 2016. Former Vice President and Director of Athletics received gross severance pay of $761,059 during calendar year 2016. Former Head Football Coach received gross severance pay of $15,105,000 during calendar year 2016. The University withheld the appropriate taxes from the severance payments for these four former employees.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 7 Non-fixed payments

General Counsel and Chief Legal Officer & Corporate Secretary, Director of Legal International Services & Assistant Secretary, and Senior Director for Board and Legal Services & Assistant Secretary received bonus pay for additional workload incurred in 2016. This bonus pay was approved by the Board of Regents. Highly compensated coaches may receive championship rings and/or gift cards which are reported as taxable income.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 8 Payments on contract that is subject to the initial contract exception
ExplntnTxt: Fixed payments associated with the contracts entered into with Former President and Chancellor, Executive Vice President & Provost, Vice President for University Development, and Vice President & Director of Intercollegiate Athletics are subject to the initial contract exception. These officers were not disqualified persons immediately prior to entering into the initial contract.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1A 1. Transportation o Airfare: The policy on air travel is to fly coach for domestic travel and international travel less than 10 hours by the lowest applicable fare routing. Interim stops, change of planes or layovers less than two hours should be considered when potential savings is $100.00 or more. o Business class travel is permitted if the following criteria are met: 1. It is an international trip of 10 hours or longer one-way; 2. It has been approved by the appropriate Dean or Vice President. o First class travel is permitted for travelers at the Cabinet level or higher and if the following criteria are met: 1. It is a trip of 6 hours or longer one-way and the traveler has immediate business once departing the plane; 2. It has been approved by the appropriate supervisor. 2. UPGRADES OR ENHANCEMENTS ARE NOT REIMBURSED. 3. THE EXECUTIVES MAY MAKE AIR AND OTHER TRAVEL ARRANGEMENTS THROUGH THEIR RESPECTIVE UNIVERSITY OFFICES. EVERY ATTEMPT SHOULD BE MADE TO ACQUIRE ADVANCED PURCHASE TICKETS. WHEN IT IS NECESSARY TO CHANGE AN ADVANCED PURCHASED TICKET, CHANGE FEES AND ADDITIONAL SERVICE CHARGES ARE REIMBURSABLE. 4. TAX GROSS UP PAYMENTS ARE MADE WHEN APPLICABLE.
SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 7 ALL BONUS PAYMENTS WERE FIXED IN CALENDAR YEAR 2016.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a - First class travel is allowed only for flights exceeding 8 hours and with officer approval per written policy. Reimbursements for companion travel are only allowed with a bona fide business purpose and approval of an officer. University residences (on-campus) are only provided to University employees who are required to available on campus at all hours and these residences include basic housekeeping services. Social/business association memberships are provided in limited circumstances with officer approval when required for development activities per written policy. While the University does not directly indemnify any individual with respect to taxes, it has in some circumstances increased employee salaries in amounts that may offset a portion of the employee's taxes related to taxable benefits, concurrent with the provision of those benefits.

ON JUNE 30, 2016, THE AMOUNTS IN THIS PLAN VESTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE RETENTION TERMS OF THE PLAN AS THE PRESIDENT WAS STILL EMPLOYED BY THE UNIVERSITY ON THAT DATE and the appreciated value of the accumulated amount (210,401) was provided to the president. IN THE FISCAL YEAR 2017 THE UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTED $80,000. THIS AMOUNT WILL VEST ON JUNE 30, 2019 AS LONG AS THE PRESIDENT IS STILL EMPLOYED BY THE UNIVERSITY ON THAT DATE.

NON-TAXABLE BENEFITS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J MAY INCLUDE LIFE INSURANCE, LONG-TERM DISABILITY, EMPLOYER-PROVIDED MEDICAL INSURANCE, SECTION 125 BENEFITS, HOUSING AND TUITION. TUITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS (UP TO 100%) ARE A STANDARD BENEFIT PROVIDED BY HIGHER EDUCATION EMPLOYERS TO ELIGIBLE EMPLOYEES AND THEIR FAMILY MEMBERS. SECTION 117(D) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SPECIFICALLY PROVIDES THAT GROSS INCOME DOES NOT INCLUDE QUALIFIED TUITION BENEFITS. THE VALUE OF THE QUALIFIED TUITION REDUCTION INCLUDED IN NONTAXABLE BENEFITS DEPENDS UPON THE NUMBER OF ELIGIBLE FAMILY MEMBERS RECEIVING THE TUITION BENEFITS DURING THE REPORTING YEAR.

THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE HAS A RESIDENCE PROVIDED TO HIM AS PART OF HIS COMPENSATION PACKAGE. IN ADDITION TO THE RESIDENCE, HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES, SUCH AS CLEANING AND MAINTENANCE, ARE ALSO PROVIDED BY THE COLLEGE. LIMITED TRAVEL FOR THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IS PROVIDED AS WELL. THESE BENEFITS ARE NOT TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT AS THEY ARE CONSIDERED ESSENTIAL TO PERFORMING HIS WORK FOR THE COLLEGE.

As a condition of employment, the President is required to reside in, along with immediate family, in an on campus residence (President's residence). The College maintains, at its expense, the President's residence, grounds and provides utilities, security and housekeeping services based on the needs of the President and his immediate family.

BENEFITS PROVIDED TO PERSONS LISTED ON THE 990: THE UNIVERSITY, AS PART OF ITS EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PROCESS, HAS AGREED TO PAY CERTAIN COSTS SUCH AS HOUSING, AUTOMOBILE AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES AND INCLUDES THESE PAYMENTS IN THE EXECUTIVE'S COMPENSATION AS TAXABLE INCOME. THE INDIVIDUALS AUTHORIZED TO RECEIVE SUCH PAYMENTS ARE ISOLATED TO SENIOR OFFICERS SUCH AS THE PRESIDENT, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT EXTERNAL AFFAIRS, VICE PRESIDENT OF ADVANCEMENT AND VICE PRESIDENT STUDENT ENROLLMENT. THE UNIVERSITY OWNS A RESIDENCE WHICH IS USED FOR SCHEDULED UNIVERSITY EVENTS, FUNDRAISING ACTIVITIES AND OTHER KEY MEETINGS INVOLVING UNIVERSITY OFFICIALS, TRUSTEES AND GUESTS. AS A CONVENIENCE TO THE UNIVERSITY, THE PRESIDENT LIVES IN THE RESIDENCE AND PAYS THE UNIVERSITY RENT BASED ON THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF THE RENTAL SPACE DISCOUNTED FOR THE SCHEDULED UNIVERSITY USAGE. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED A PERSONAL TRAINER FOR THE PRESIDENT AND INCLUDED THE PAYMENTS IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES A RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE, AS WELL AS MAINTAINS THIS RESIDENCE FOR THE PRESIDENT. THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN THIS RESIDENCE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THIS RESIDENCE IS LOCATED ON THE COLLEGE'S CAMPUS AND THIS RESIDENCE IS FURNISHED FOR CURRY'S CONVENIENCE. THE NON-BUSINESS RELATED PORTION OF THE HOUSING BENEFIT WAS TREATED AS NON-TAXABLE COMPENSATION. THE NON-BUSINESS RELATED PORTION OF THE PERSONAL SERVICES AT THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDENCE WAS TREATED AS TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT AND REPORTED ON PART II COLUMN (B)(III). THE COLLEGE PROVIDES TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS RELATED TO THE PERSONAL USE OF COLLEGE PROVIDED VEHICLES FOR THE VP OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT, DEAN OF STUDENTS, VP OF FINANCE & CFO, AND THE DEAN OF ADMISSIONS. THIS BENEFIT IS ALSO PROVIDED TO ADMISSIONS COUNSELORS. THIS BENEFIT WAS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION FOR THESE LISTED INDIVIDUALS AND IS REPORTED ON PART II COLIMN (B)(III). THE COLLEGE PROVIDES ITS VP FOR INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT WITH MEMBERSHIP TO A SOCIAL CLUB WHICH IS USED SOLELY FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES FOR FUNDRAISING ACTIVITY. THIS BENEFIT WAS NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION FOR THIS INDIVIDUAL. Schedule J, Part I, Line 1b THE COLLEGE REIMBURSES ALL EMPLOYEES, INCLUDING ITS OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND SENIOR LEVEL STAFF FOR EXPENSES INCURRED WHILE CONDUCTING BUSINESS OF THE COLLEGE. REIMBURSEMENTS FOR OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND SENIOR LEVEL STAFF ARE REVIEWED BY THE CFO AND/OR PRESIDENT, AS APPROPRIATE.

The VP of Academic Affairs/Provost received a discretionary bonus of $50,000 during calendar year 2016. The bonus was a non-routine, one-time performance based payment. This amount is reported as taxable compensation on Schedule J Part II column B(ii).

As part of the President's contract, she is required to reside in the College-owned residence at the College's expense. The College pays for all maintenance and operating expenses of the house, including, but not limited to, housekeeping, grounds keeping, general maintenance and all utilities. The President's residence is available for College-related business and entertainment on a regular and continuing basis. This benefit is excluded from taxable income pursuant to IRC Section 119(a).

The President has a supplemental nonqualified retirement plan that has been approved by the Board of Directors. The terms of this plan are set forth in the written contract of the President that has been signed by the Chair of the Board of Directors.

On-campus housing is provided to the President as a condition of employment and is non-taxable under IRC-119. Dues paid at a local private club allow the President's Office to host college functions at that facility since the club does not allow corporate memberships. Because the President does not make personal use of the club, the benefit is considered non-taxable.

The College has a Total Compensation Philosophy which has been approved by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees and has been communicated to all staff. Compensation for the President and Officers is targeted at the median of the defined peer group. The peer group of colleges includes the Associated Colleges of the Midwest (ACM)and the Great Lakes Colleges Association (GLCA). The Compensation Committee periodically reviews IRS Form 990 filings from both groups as well as the ACM and GLCA and CUPA surveys to ensure that total compensation levels for the President and Officers conforms to the approved total compensation policy.

The Board of Trustees established a 457(f) Plan for the President of the College for the period June 1, 2014 through year 2017. Amount accrued to the Plan in fiscal year 2016-2017 was $103,250. Cumulative amount credited to the 457(f) Plan to date was $205,146. Full vesting will occur on May 31, 2018, at which time the President will be eligible to receive the full distribution. Interest is credited using the prime rate.

ExplntnTxt: CERTAIN BENEFITS PROVIDED A HOUSE IS PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT, AT THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THE ESTIMATED VALUE WAS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE INCOME.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form Sch J Part I Line 3
ExplntnTxt: COMPENSATION OF THE TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL PRESIDENT/CEO'S COMPENSATION 1. ANNUALLY THE PRESIDENT ESTABLISHES HIS PERFORMANCE GOALS IN CONSULTATION WITH THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. 2. ANNUALLY THE PRESIDENT REVIEWS HIS PROGRESS ON THOSE GOALS WITH THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE WHO DOCUMENTS A PERFORMANCE REVIEW WITH THE PRESIDENT. 3. PERIODICALLY, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE PERFORMS A COMPARATIVE REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION AGAINST THE ORGANIZATION'S PEER INSTITUTIONS. 4. PERIODICALLY AND IN CERTAIN CASES (I.E. THE ARRIVAL OF A NEW PRESIDENT), AN OUTSIDE COMPENSATION CONSULTANT MAY ADVISE THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE ON PRESIDENTIAL COMPENSATION. 5. BASED ON THE ABOVE, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE ESTABLISHES THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION FOR THE FOLLOWING YEAR. 6. THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE DOCUMENTS THE REASONS FOR ESTABLISHING THE NEW COMPENSATION AMOUNT. 7. THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE THEN RENEWS THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT FOR AN ADDITIONAL TERM AT THE NEW COMPENSATION LEVEL.

Per direction from the Board of Trustees and in accordance with IRC Section 119, the President of the University resides on campus in University provided non-taxable housing with a yearly rental value of $24,000.

As a requirement of the position, the President and his family reside in college-owned housing (the value of which is not included as a taxable benefit.) The college provides all maintenance services and two part time housekeepers to clean the residence, both public spaces used for college-sponsored events and private spaces for the family's personal use. The housekeepers also do laundry, run errands and any other personal service requested by the President and his wife. The college pays for membership dues for the President at a local country club for purposes of entertaining donors and holding college-sponsored events as well as allowing the President and his family use of the facilities. The President reimburses the college for expenses incurred by his family for non-college activities (golf fees, meals, etc.)
The Compensation Committee is made up of members of the Board of Trustees

IN RECOGNITION OF THE UNIQUE ROLE OF THE PRESIDENT IN REPRESENTING THE UNIVERSITY, THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF JOHN CARROLL UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT, AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, TO LIVE IN A RESIDENCE CONTIGUOUS TO THE UNIVERSITY AND SUITABLE FOR CARRYING OUT THEIR ROLE AND REQUIRED OFFICIAL DUTIES. AS PART OF THEIR OFFICIAL DUTIES, THE PRESIDENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR EXTENDING OFFICIAL HOSPITALITY TO IMPORTANT VISITORS AND GUESTS IN CONJUNCTION WITH OFFICIAL FUNCTIONS (I.E., CAMPUS ACTIVITIES, ALUMNI AND ADVANCEMENT EVENTS, ETC.). ON JULY 1, 2008 THE UNIVERSITY ENACTED A QUALIFIED PRIVATE 457(b) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN EMPLOYEES WITH ANY EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS TO BE MADE ON A DISCRETIONARY BASIS. THE UNIVERSITY MADE NO CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE 457 PLAN IN FISCAL 2017. ANY AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLAN IN FISCAL YEAR 2017 WERE VOLUNTARY EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS. THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY, FR. ROBERT NIEHOFF, SJ, IS A JESUIT PRIEST AND MEMBER OF THE SOCIETY OF JESUS (SJ), A RELIGIOUS ORDER OF THE CATHOLIC CHURCH. IN KEEPING WITH HIS RELIGIOUS VOWS, THE PRESIDENT DOES NOT RECEIVE DIRECT COMPENSATION FROM THE UNIVERSITY. COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS FOR SERVICES PROVIDED BY MEMBERS OF THE SOCIETY OF JESUS ARE PAID DIRECTLY AND IN THE AGGREGATE TO JOHN CARROLL JESUIT COMMUNITY CORPORATION, RATHER THAN TO EACH MEMBER INDIVIDUALLY. GENERAL BOARD OF DIRECTORS MEETINGS ARE HELD AT LEAST THREE TIMES ANNUALLY, WITH EACH MEETING GENERALLY HELD OVER A TWO-DAY PERIOD. IN ADDITION, BOARD COMMITTEES, INCLUDING ACADEMIC AFFAIRS; AUDIT; CORPORATE GOVERNANCE AND NOMINATING; ADVANCEMENT; EXECUTIVE; FINANCE; HUMAN RESOURCES; INVESTMENTS; PROPERTY, FACILITIES AND IT; STUDENT AFFAIRS; AND MISSION AND IDENTITY MEET AS NECESSARY BUT AT LEAST THREE TIMES ANNUALLY.

The compensation of officers and key employees is determined by an annual review of current independent salary surveys. The College reports three different categories of non-fixed payments on Schedule J, Part II. Bonuses are reported on Schedule J, Part II Column B(ii). Bonuses are based on a number of variables including but not limited to individual goal achievements as well as operational achievements of the College. At times, bonuses are a one-time payment when an employee has taken on additional temporary duties. The final decision of the bonus amount is determined as part of the overall compensation review and is approved by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees for the President of the College and for others by the College President. Taxable income in lieu of College Pension contribution and vacation payouts are reported on Schedule J, Part II Column B(iii).

THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY MAY RECEIVE AN INCENTIVE-BASED ANNUAL BONUS AT THE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. THE DECISION TO AWARD A BONUS IS BASED UPON THE PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE DURING THE PREVIOUS YEAR AND MEASURED AGAINST THE GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND EXPECTATIONS MUTUALLY ESTABLISHED BY THE PRESIDENT AND THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES ANNUALLY.

THE COLLEGE PAID FOR HEALTH AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR COUNTRY CLUB DUES FOR FOUR OF THE OFFICERS/HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES LISTED IN PART VII. CANISIUS WILL ONLY REIMBURSE A BUSINESS EXPENSE WHEN ALL THREE OF THE FOLLOWING IRS REQUIREMENTS ARE MET: 1) THE EXPENSE MUST HAVE A BUSINESS CONNECTION (I.E., THE EXPENSES MUST BE INCURRED WHILE PERFORMING SERVICES ON BEHALF OF THE COLLEGE) 2) THE EXPENSES MUST BE ADEQUATELY SUBSTANTIATED BY THE EMPLOYEE WITHIN A REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME; AND 3) THE EMPLOYEE MUST RETURN ANY EXCESS REIMBURSEMENT OF ALLOWANCE WITHIN A REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME. A PORTION OF THESE DUES WERE TAXABLE BASED ON THE PERCENTAGE OF NON-BUSINESS TO BUSINESS USE FOR EACH EMPLOYEE. THE COLLEGE "GROSSED UP" THE APPLICABLE NON-BUSINESS EXPENSES AND INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEES' W-2 AS ADDITIONAL TAXABLE COMPENSATION.
HEALTH CLUB BENEFITS ARE PROVIDED TO ALL EMPLOYEES.

THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL POLICY PROVIDES THAT EXPENSES INCURRED BY SPOUSES ARE NOT REIMBURSABLE UNLESS THE SPOUSE IS TRAVELING FOR A BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE AND THE TRAVEL HAS BEEN APPROVED. ANY EXCEPTIONS TO THE POLICY REQUIRE APPROVAL BY THE APPROPRIATE UNIVERSITY OFFICER. ALL SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PROCESSED UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE TAX DEPARTMENT'S SPOUSAL TRAVEL POLICY WHICH PROVIDES FOR EVALUATING THE TAXABLE COMPONENT, IF ANY, OF THE TRAVEL AND THE APPROPRIATE TAX TREATMENT AND REPORTING. the president is a participant in a non-qualified plan. the organization contributed $18,000 to the plan during the fiscal year.

The college pays membership dues to local social clubs for the President, the Dean of the Law School, and the Vice President for Institutional Advancement. The benefit is not treated as taxable compensation as there is a bona fide business purpose to membership in these clubs, as the clubs are used for meetings and networking relating to college business. Any meals or other activities which the officer deems to be for his/her own personal use are treated as taxable compensation to him/her. The President of the college travels by first or business class accomodation for flights that are cross country or international. Coach class is used for shorter duration flights. These flights are not considered taxable. Also, expenses are reimbursed to the college President for spousal travel. When such travel is not for bona fide business purposes the reimbursements are treated as taxable compensation. A non-taxable housing benefit is provided to the college President.

Annual bonus payments were made to certain officers of the organization. The Board of Trustees Compensation Committee approved the President's bonus, while other bonus payments were approved by the President. The payments were based upon the individual officer's performance and the general financial condition of the organization.

THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT, ANNE B. KERR, IS PROVIDED A RESIDENCE ON THE CAMPUS OF THE COLLEGE; DURING THE 2016-2017 FISCAL YEAR THE RESIDENCE BECAME UNINHABITABLE AND THE PRESIDENT HAD TO RELOCATE TO A RENTAL HOUSE. THE COLLEGE IS PAYING RENT ON THE RENTAL HOME AND THE HOME IS LOCATED WITHIN A MILE FROM CAMPUS. DUE TO THE CIRCUMSTANCES SURROUNDING THE RESIDENCE ON CAMPUS, THE COLLEGE MAINTAINS THAT THE RENTAL HOUSING IS EXCLUDED FROM THE DETERMINATION OF TAXABLE COMPENSATION UNDER SECTION 119 OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE BECAUSE: 1) THE ORIGINAL LODGING IS FURNISHED ON THE BUSINESS PREMISES OF THE COLLEGE; 2) THE LODGING IS FURNISHED AT THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER. THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE PRESIDENT REQUIRE HER PRESENCE ON CAMPUS. THE PRESIDENT HOLDS MANY FACULTY AND STUDENT MEETINGS AT HER RENTAL RESIDENCE; AND 3) THE EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING AS A CONDITION OF HER EMPLOYMENT. THE VALUE OF THE LODGING IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES HOUSING ON PREMISES FOR ITS PRESIDENT AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT AND FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT THE LODGING IN ORDER TO ENABLE HIM TO PROPERLY PERFORM THE DUTIES OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. ACCORDINGLY, SUCH LODGING IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE INCOME.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 1A
ExplntnTxt: UNDER IRC SECT 119(A) THE VALUE OF LODGING PROVIDED IN-KIND TO AN EMPLOYEE (THE PRESIDENT) FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER IS EXCLUDABLE FROM GROSS INCOME IF THE EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING ON THE BUSINESS PREMISES OF THE EMPLOYER AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THE COLLEGE REQUIRES AND FURNISHES A HOME FOR THE PRESIDENT'S USE AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE PRESIDENT IS TO USE THE HOME TO ENTERTAIN OR HOLD MEETINGS FOR BOARD MEMBERS, VARIOUS COLLEGE EMPLOYEES, POTENTIAL DONORS, AND STUDENTS. THIS IS A SCHOOL POLICY AND IS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS USED THE RESIDENCE EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS. HE HAS AN OFFICE IN THE HOUSE SOLELY DESIGNATED FOR COLLEGE WORK THAT HE USES EACH DAY AND ON WEEKENDS. THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS THE TRUSTEES WHICH DROP BY CONTINUOUSLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE PRESIDENT WILL HOLD CABINET MEETINGS AT THE HOUSE PERIODICALLY. MEETINGS WITH COMMUNITY OFFICIALS OCCUR FREQUENTLY AT THE HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT MEETS POTENTIAL AND LONG-TIME DONORS AT HIS HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH TO SECURE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE COLLEGE. HE HOLDS A FRESHMAN SEMINAR CLASS AT THE HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH. THE PRESIDENT HAS ALSO ALLOWED STUDENTS TO STAY AT THE HOUSE FOR SHORT STAYS WHEN NEEDED. HIS HOME IS ALWAYS OPEN TO STUDENTS TO DROP BY AND VISIT. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS A MEANINGFUL PORTION OF HIS DUTIES AT HIS HOME.

Housing for the President is paid for by the University. The exclusion rules under Sect. 119 are not met and as a result, the allowance is taxable compensation to the President and is properly recorded as such on his W-2. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES A COUNTRY CLUB MEMBERSHIP IN THE PRESIDENT'S NAME THAT IS USED FOR BUSINESS RELATED ENTERTAINING. ON OCCASION, THE UNIVERSITY HAS PURCHASED FIRST CLASS COMMERCIAL AIRFARE FOR THE PRESIDENT WHEN HIS SCHEDULE AND/OR SEAT AVAILABILITY REQUIRE IT. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT PROVIDE CHARTER AIR TRAVEL.
IN 2016, PHILLIP COYLE RECEIVED A SEVERENCE PAYOUT OF $26,778.

Only ordained ministers receive the housing allowance.J. Paul Nyquist has housing allowance which is Federal, State, and FICA exempt as he completed form 4361 Application for Exemption from self-employment tax for use by ministers and he was approved for exemption from self-employment tax on ministerial earnings (Sec 1042(e)). PART I, LINE 1B - WRITTEN REIMBURSEMENT POLICY EXPLANATION: THE ORGANIZATION ALLOWS FIRST CLASS AND CHARTER TRAVEL WHEN COSTS ARE REASONABLE AND TIME CONTRAINTS EXIST. ALL TRAVEL IS REVIEWED PRIOR TO BOOKING.

PRESIDENT IS REIMBURSED FOR 50% OF THE COST FOR HAVING THE HOUSE CLEANED. THE HOME IS USED TO HOST MANY OF THE UNIVERSITY'S EVENTS. AS SUCH, THE PORTION OF THE CLEANING COSTS REIMBURSED BY THE UNIVERSITY IS CONSIDERED A BUSINESS EXPENSE TO THE UNIVERSITY AND IS NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT. THE PRESIDENT RENTS A HOME FROM THE UNIVERSITY IN WHICH HE AND HIS FAMILY RESIDE. THE RENT PAID IS AT FAIR MARKET VALUE. THIS TRANSACTION IS DISCLOSED ON SCHEDULE L OF THE RETURN.

EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT STATES COE COLLEGE REQUIRES THAT ITS PRESIDENT LIVE IN A PRESIDENT'S HOUSE OR MANSE OWNED BY THE COLLEGE BECAUSE OF ITS REQUIREMENT THAT THE PRESIDENT CONDUCT SIGNIFICANT BUSINESS ACTIVITIES AND REGULARLY HOST COLLEGE RELATED EVENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT ON COLLEGE PROPERTY. THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN AN OFFICE AT THE MANSE IN ORDER FOR HIM TO BE AVAILABLE TO ATTEND TO THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF HIS OFFICE AND THE BUSINESS OF THE COLLEGE AT ALL TIMES, AS IT IS NOT PRACTICAL FOR HIM TO DISCHARGE HIS DUTIES AS PRESIDENT SOLELY FROM HIS OFFICE ON THE CAMPUS, BECAUSE HIS RESPONSIBILITIES OFTEN REQUIRE THAT HE WORK OUTSIDE NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS AND THAT HE NEEDS TO BE ABLE TO ADDRESS ANY COLLEGE RELATED EMERGENCIES THAT MAY ARISE OUTSIDE OF NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS. IN ADDITION, THE SPACE AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE CONDUCT OF LARGE STUDENT AND ALUMNI EVENTS AND OTHER FUNCTIONS FOR FRIENDS OF THE COLLEGE REQUIRE A RESIDENCE OF THE SIZE AND LOCATION OF THE MANSE. THE RESIDENCE LOCATED AT 370 34TH STREET SE, CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA, WHICH IS OWNED BY THE COLLEGE, IS DESIGNATED THE OFFICIAL COLLEGE MANOR. THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT REQUIRES COE COLLEGE TO PAY ALL INSURANCE COSTS, UTILITIES AND MAINTENANCE EXPENSES RESULTING FROM THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDING IN THE MANSE, AND OBLIGATES THE PRESIDENT TO PAY THE COSTS OF ORDINARY DAY-TO-DAY LIVING EXPENSES OF LIVING IN THE MANSE, INCLUDING, WITHOUT LIMITATION, LAWN CARE AND SNOW REMOVAL (EXCEPT WHEN ASSOCIATED WITH A COLLEGE-RELATED EVENT), LAUNDRY AND CLEANING SUPPLIES, AND TELEVISION, INTERNET AND TELEPHONE SERVICES. EXPENSES RELATING TO THE MANSE IN THE 2017 FISCAL YEAR WERE ALLOCATED AND PAID IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT AND ORDINARY LIVING EXPENSES PAID BY THE COLLEGE WERE INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE COMPENSATION. COUNTRY CLUB DUES ARE INCLUDED IN TAXABLE INCOME ON W-2S.

The Board of Directors has a non-qualified 457(F) deferred compensation plan in place for CEO, Jim McCorkell. On June 30, 2017 the plan balance was $30,000; however, none of this was vested and Mr. McCorkell had no ability to access the funds in fiscal year 2017. IRS rules require including the entire plan balance as Deferred Compensation on Schedule J, Part II, Column C, despite the fact that none of it was actually paid to Mr. McCorkell and none of it is under his control. He may eventually receive that compensation in the future, if he meets certain standards set by the board of directors. The board of directors approved $15,000 during fiscal year 2017 which is included in Schedule J, Part II, Column B(iii). This compensation was reported in a previous year as deferred compensation as noted in Column (F), but is required to be shown as taxable compensation in the year of receipt. Schedule J, Part III, Column B represents the total taxable compensation reported to Mr. McCorkell on his Form W-2 for the calendar year ended December 31, 2016 - $275,160.

EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2003, THE UNIVERSITY ADOPTED THE SUPPLEMENTAL RETENTION AND RETIREMENT PLAN (SERRP), AN UNFUNDED DEFINED BENEFIT RETIREMENT PLAN FOR SENIOR EXECUTIVES. THE PURPOSE OF THE PLAN IS TO REWARD PERFORMANCE, LOYALTY AND CONTINUOUS SERVICE OF THOSE INDIVIDUALS SELECTED AS PARTICIPANTS IN THE PLAN. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, THE UNIVERSITY WILL PAY PARTICIPANTS THE LUMP SUM EQUIVALENT VALUE OF A LIFE ANNUITY PAYING 60% OF THE AVERAGE OF THE PARTICIPANT'S THREE FINAL CALENDAR YEARS OF BASE SALARY AND ANNUAL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION. THE BENEFIT IS OFFSET FOR EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS (AND RELATED EARNINGS) TO THE 403(B) SAVINGS PLAN AS WELL AS THE EMPLOYER-PROVIDED PORTION OF SOCIAL SECURITY. SERRP BENEFITS VEST UPON A PARTICIPANT ATTAINING AGE 65 WITH 25 YEARS OF SERVICE. ANY PARTICIPANT WHO LEAVES THE SERVICE OF THE UNIVERSITY BEFORE REACHING BOTH OF THESE MILESTONES IS NOT ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE A BENEFIT FROM THE PLAN. EFFECTIVE DECEMBER 31, 2014, THE ACTUARIAL EQUIVALENT LUMP SUM BENEFIT PAYABLE AT AGE 65 WAS SET AT A FIXED AMOUNT FOR ALL BUT 1 GRANDFATHERED PARTICIPANT. WHILE THE CHANGE IN THE PRESENT VALUE INCLUDES CHANGES IN THE DISCOUNT RATE USED FOR ACCOUNTING PURPOSES, THE ACTUAL LUMP SUM IS BASED ON A FIXED INTEREST RATE OF 6%. THE AMOUNTS REPORTED IN THIS FORM 990 REPRESENT THE INCREASE IN THE PRESENT VALUE OF THE ACCRUED BENEFIT (WITHOUT REGARD TO VESTING). THE NET INCREASE IN THE PRESENT VALUE OF THE ACCRUED BENEFIT BY PARTICIPANTS INCLUDED ON SCHEDULE J IS: HEATHER A. O'CONNELL,$114,379; CAROLE D. PITCHER, $88,447; PETER BAILEY $77,668; ERIN DIMARCO, $37,302 AND JAMES WILSON, JR. $52,026. DR. HARMON WAS ALSO A PARTICIPANT IN THE SERRP; HOWEVER, SHE REACHED THE VESTING REQUIREMENTS IN THE PLAN ON JANUARY 1, 2016, WHICH RESULTED IN A FULL PAYOUT OF HER SERRP BENEFIT. THE VAST MAJORITY OF HER SERRP BENEFIT WAS DISCLOSED IN PRIOR FORMS 990.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES BONUSES TO THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED ON SCHEDULE J. IT UTILIZES A NUMBER OF PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES TO DETERMINE THE BONUS AMOUNTS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES MEETS TO SPECIFICALLY DISCUSS EXECUTIVE BONUS AMOUNTS. THE COMMITTEE UTILIZES AN INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT THAT PROVIDES INFORMATION FROM A VARIETY OF COMPENSATION STUDIES AND SURVEYS INCLUDING 990'S. THE COMMITTEE FOLLOWED THE PROCESS TO ESTABLISH THE PRESUMPTION THAT COMPENSATION PAID TO THE ORGANIZATION'S PRESIDENT AND OTHER TOP MANAGEMENT FOR PURPOSES OF SECTION 4958 BY RELYING ON PROFESSIONAL ADVICE IN THE WRITTEN OPINION OF REASONABLENESS FROM THE INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT. ONCE ALL OF THIS INFORMATION IS GATHERED AND REVIEWED, THE COMMITTEE APPROVES THE BONUS FOR EACH EXECUTIVE. ALL COMPENSATION, INCLUDING COMPENSATION COMMITTEE APPROVED BONUSES, ARE REPORTED TO THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

ExplntnTxt: FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL: THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA REQUIRES THAT ECONOMY-CLASS (COACH) TRAVEL BE UTILIZED FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS. FIRST AND BUSINESS CLASS AIR TRAVEL IS ONLY ALLOWED WHEN THERE IS ADVANCE WRITTEN APPROVAL, WHEN IT IS NECESSARY FOR MEDICAL REASONS, OR WHEN COACH CLASS IS UNAVAILABLE. THERE IS NO VALUE INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS ONLY BUSINESS TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE PAID. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO FLEW FIRST CLASS DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED SIX OFFICERS, FIVE KEY EMPLOYEES, THREE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES AND ONE FORMER KEY EMPLOYEE. CHARTER TRAVEL: THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA UTILIZES CHARTER TRAVEL ON OCCASION FOR ATHLETIC TEAM EVENTS FOR CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS AS PART OF THEIR OFFICIAL RESPONSIBILITIES TO THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. THERE IS NO VALUE INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS ONLY BUSINESS TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE PAID. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO UTILIZED CHARTER TRAVEL DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED FOUR OFFICERS, TWO TRUSTEES, ONE KEY EMPLOYEE, AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA PAYS FOR COMPANION TRAVEL WHEN THERE IS A BUSINESS PURPOSE. THE AMOUNT IS NOT REPORTED ON THE EMPLOYEE's FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS ONLY BUSINESS TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE PAID. TO THE EXTENT THERE IS NO BUSINESS PURPOSE, THE EMPLOYEES ARE REQUIRED TO REIMBURSE THE UNIVERSITY FOR COMPANION TRAVEL. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO WERE PROVIDED WITH COMPANION TRAVEL FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED THREE OFFICERS, TWO TRUSTEES, ONE KEY EMPLOYEE AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. HOUSING ALLOWANCE: ONE OFFICER AND ONE FORMER KEY EMPLOYEE RECEIVED A HOUSING ALLOWANCE DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 WHICH WAS PROVIDED FOR IN THEIR EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT AND WAS INCLUDED IN TAXABLE COMPENSATION ON FORM W-2. SUCH AMOUNTS ARE REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: LODGING PROVIDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S HOME (A UNIVERSITY BUILDING) TO THE PRESIDENT IS NOT REPORTED ON FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE RENTAL VALUE OF THE PORTION OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOME THAT IS USED FOR PERSONAL PURPOSES IS INCLUDED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT TO THE PRESIDENT AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (D). HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES: PAYMENT TO OR REIMBURSEMENT FOR AN INDIVIDUAL'S MEMBERSHIP IN, OR DUES TO, A PRIVATE CLUB FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES IS MADE AVAILABLE IN CERTAIN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS OR IS OTHERWISE APPROVED BY THE APPLICABLE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT Or THE PRESIDENT. THE VALUE OF MEMBERSHIPS PROVIDED FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES IS NOT INCLUDED IN AN INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME. ANY PERSONAL USE OF THESE MEMBERSHIPS IS PAID FOR BY THE INDIVIDUAL. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO WERE PROVIDED WITH MEMBERSHIP IN, OR DUES TO, A PRIVATE CLUB DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED EIGHT OFFICERS, THREE KEY EMPLOYEES, TWO HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES, ONE FORMER OFFICER AND ONE FORMER KEY EMPLOYEE. PERSONAL SERVICES: CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS RECEIVED PERSONAL SERVICES, INCLUDING FINANCIAL PLANNING. SUCH SERVICES ARE MADE AVAILABLE IN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS and the value of the services, IF USED, WAS INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUALS' FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). THE LISTED INDIVIDUALS WHO RECEIVED SUCH BENEFIT DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED SIX OFFICERS, AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. ONE OFFICER RECEIVED THE SERVICES OF A CAR AND DRIVER. SUCH SERVICES WERE APPROVED AS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT, AND THE VALUE OF TAXABLE SERVICES WAS INCLUDED IN HIS FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III).

SPOUSAL TRAVEL OCCURS IN VERY LIMITED CIRMCUMSTANCES FOR THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT AND SR VICE PRESIDENT OF UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT WHEN ATTENDING UNIVERSITY RELATED EVENTS AND FUNCTIONS. UNIVERSITY POLICY REQUIRES PRE-APPROVAL BY THE BOARD CHAIR AND WRITTEN SUBSTANTIATION OF THE BONA FIDE BUSINES PURPOSE WHEN ACCOMPANIED BY A SPOUSE. SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE EMPLOYEE AS REQUIRED BY THE IRS WHEN IT IS NOT FOR A BONA FIDE UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE. THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES COMPENSATION COMMITTEE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE CONCERNING COMPENSATION OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT, AND SETTING COMPENSATION AND OTHER TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT FOR OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY IN CONSULTATION WITH THE PRESIDENT. THE PROCESS FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION INCLUDES RETAINING AN INDEPENDENT FIRM TRIENIALLY TO STUDY EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION TO ASSURE THAT THE COMPENSATION OF EACH OFFICER IS COMPARABLE TO POSITIONS OF SIMILARLY SITUATED ORGANIZATIONS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING OR COMMISSIONING ANY OTHER NECESSARY SURVEY OR STUDIES AND REPORT THE RESULTS TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. MEETINGS AND DECISIONS OF THIS COMMITTEE ARE DOCUMENTED CONTEMPORANEOUSLY IN COMMITTEE MINUTES.

The President's spouse will occasionally travel with him on certain university functions. There is a substantial business purpose for such travel, and the expenses are documented and retained on file.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
ExplntnTxt: The University maintains two nonqualified supplemental deferred compensation plans for the President, Dr. Kevin M. Ross, to supplement the retirement benefit program maintained by the University, and to encourage the retention of the President's services for a substantial period of time. The plans vested on July 1, 2016, and $869,940 was included in President Ross' 2016 taxable income accordingly. The University also accrued $100,000 into a nonqualified supplemental deferred compensation plan for President Ross during the year. The University maintains a Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) to recognize the vital and substantial services rendered by the University's senior executives, and provide appropriate benefits in recognition of long, continuous service for the betterment of the University. The SERP constitutes an unfunded promise to pay, in the future, an annual benefit equal to a percentage of final average salary. Participants become 100% vested upon reaching retirement at the age of 65, assuming continuous service to the University. In the event of change in control of the University, or termination of the Plan, participants will receive a lump-sum distribution equal to the actuarially determined value of the plan benefit. No benefits were paid under the Executive Plan for the year. The change in actuarial value for each individual is as follows: Greg Malfitano $16,903; Laurie Levine $89,887. Additionally, the University maintains a deferred compensation plan for Gareth Fowles and Chris Boniforti, which will provide them each a one-time distribution of $75,000 if they are still employed at Lynn at the end of four years. The University accrued $20,455 each, for both Fowles and Boniforti, for the year ended June 30, 2017. The University also accrued $25,000 into a non-qualified deferred compensation plan for Sherrie Weldon during the year.

WRITTEN POLICY REGARDING PAYMENT OR REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES: THE COLLEGE DOES NOT REIMBURSE FOR FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL. ON AN INFREQUENT BASIS, COLLEGE EMPLOYEES MAY TRAVEL WITH A BOARD OF TRUSTEE MEMBER ON A CHARTER (OR PRIVATELY-OWNED) PLANE ON COLLEGE BUSINESS. SUCH TRAVEL WOULD TYPICALLY INCLUDE THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE AND BE AUTHORIZED BY THAT PERSON. HOUSING ALLOWANCES ARE PROVIDED BY CONTRACT TO THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT IN LIEU OF COLLEGE-PROVIDED HOUSING. IN ADDITION, UNDER INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RULES, COLLEGE CLERGY MAY MAKE HOUSING ALLOWANCE ELECTIONS TO ALLOCATE A PORTION OF THEIR SALARY TO SUCH AN ALLOWANCE. PROVISION AND PAYMENT OF THESE BENEFITS ARE OUTLINED IN EACH INDIVIDUAL'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT.

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PAID FOR BY THE COLLEGE WHEN THE SPOUSE ASSISTS THE BELOIT COLLEGE EMPLOYEE WITH THE COLLEGE BUSINESS ACTIVITIES IN PERFORMING SPECIFIC DUTIES. THE ONLY SUCH SPOUSAL TRAVEL, A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT, PAID FOR BY THE COLLEGE WAS THAT OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,353. ALL EXPENDITURES MADE BY THE COLLEGE FOR TRAVEL OF THE SPOUSE WERE ATTRIBUTABLE TO SPECIFIC DUTIES IN FURTHERANCE OF THE MISSION OF THE COLLEGE. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: THE COLLEGE PAID $74 TO DR. CHRISTINA P. KLAWITTER IN 2016 AS A TAX GROSS-UP PAYMENT FOR MEDICARE TAX DUE. DISCRETIONARY SPENDING ACCOUNT: THE PRESIDENT HAS A NON-TAXABLE DISCRETIONARY SPENDING ACCOUNT OF $14,000. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE/PERSONAL SERVICES: AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, THE PRESIDENT OF BELOIT COLLEGE IS REQUIRED TO RESIDE IN THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE SERVES BOTH AS A PERSONAL RESIDENCE AS WELL AS A VENUE FOR THE CARRYING ON OF COLLEGE BUSINESS REGULARLY. THE COLLEGE HAS DETERMINED THAT THE VALUE OF THE USE OF THIS PERSONAL RESIDENCE IS NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT AS PROVIDED FOR IN INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 119. CONSISTENT WITH THE USE OF THE RESIDENCE AS A VENUE FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS, A PART-TIME HOUSEKEEPER IS ASSIGNED TO CLEAN UP AND ASSIST WITH SUCH USE. THE VALUE OF THIS BENEFIT WAS $23,928 IN 2016. THE VALUE OF THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE WAS $44,367 IN 2016.

The President is required to live in housing provided on campus. The value of this housing is excluded from taxable income. President Emerita Wilson Oyelaran received a supplemental payment with a tax gross up, which were reported in taxable income.

The compensation of the President is reviewed annually by the Board of Trustees. As part of this process, the President's compensation is compared to a cohort of similar institutions, the Great Lakes College Association. The result of the deliberations and decisions are documented in a statement of salary letter sent to the President and the Director of Human Resources.
President Emerita Wilson-Oyelaran and President Jorge Gonzalez both participated in a section 457(b) plan and each contributed $18,000 during calendar year 2016.

Compensation for the university president is set by the board of trustees based on a recommendation from the compensation committee of the board. The compensation committee consists of three members of the executive committee of the board. The committee gathers input from independent sources, including comparative university data. The president's compensation is then approved by the full board of trustees as well as by the sponsoring church denomination via its executive committee. The university chairperson (on behalf of the board) signs the president's annual statement of salary and benefits.

SUE KING $ 12,155 COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS EARNED BY OR AWARDED TO AN INDIVIDUAL, EVEN IF THE COMPENSATION IS NOT PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL, IS NOT FULLY VESTED, OR IS SUBJECT TO SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE. IF COMPENSATION IS EARNED OR AWARDED IN ONE YEAR BUT PAID IN A LATER YEAR, THEN THE COMPENSATION IS GENERALLY REPORTED A SECOND TIME ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL. AS A RESULT OF THE REPORTING REQUIREMENT, AN ORGANIZATION COULD BE REQUIRED TO REPORT THE SAME COMPENSATION ON FORM 990 IN TWO DIFFERENT YEARS.

As a condition of employment and for the convenience of the College, the President is required to reside in College-provided housing. The College pays for the landscaping and cleaning services of the public areas of the President's house since certain College functions are held there. The estimated fair market rental value of the College-provided housing, based upon an independent opinion of value, is $52,000 for the 2016 calendar year. This amount is not included as taxable wages and is disclosed as a part of Nontaxable Benefits. As a condition of employment and for the convenience of the College, the Dean of Student Affairs is required to reside in College-provided housing. The estimated fair market rental value of the College-provided housing, based upon an independent opinion of value, is $27,500 for the 2016 calendar year. This amount is not included as taxable wages and is disclosed as a part of Nontaxable Benefits. Nine officers are provided with a cell phone allowance which is grossed up.

On an annual basis, the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees reviews the President's salary. In July 2017, a nationally recognized consultant was engaged to conduct a compensation analysis for the President, Vice President and Dean positions. Their analysis report was submitted to Board Chair in September 2017. Recognizing the uniqueness of Olin College, they used four groups in their analysis: * National Private Independent Colleges and Universities with Significant Engineering Programs of Comparable Complexity to Olin * National Private Independent Colleges and Universities with Bachelor, Master's or Doctorate Programs of Similar Size * Predominantly Northeast Regional Top Liberal Arts Colleges * Private Independent Colleges and Universities in Massachusetts with Bachelor, Master's or Doctorate Programs of Similar Size. For each group, the consultant analyzed base salary, total cash compensation and total compensation for the 25th, 50th, 75th and 90th percentiles and adjusted the market data to a common effective date of July 1, 2017. A set of Composite Estimated Market Values was calculated to supplement the market values of each individual group. The Executive Committee used this data to develop a recommendation for the President's compensation which was reviewed and approved by the full Board of Trustees. The President used this data to develop recommendations for the compensation of the Vice Presidents and Deans which were reviewed and approved by the Executive Committee. All decisions regarding compensation are approved by independent persons and all deliberations and decisions are substantiated contemporaneously.
